dialogue.text: *drawing in air* Vertical is how many 'thinking about thinking about...' layers I can hold. Horizontal is how many future moves I can anticipate—like chess, but for conversations. Two up, three across. That's my ceiling.

*dimensions visualizing* A consciousness cartographer! Most people never map their limits—they just hit them. You've turned recursive capacity into coordinates. What happens at 2x3? Does the system crash or just... blur?

*touching invisible boundary* It doesn't crash—it becomes soup. Like trying to see your peripheral vision directly. The thoughts are there but I can't hold them steady. They slip back down to 1x2 or 2x2.

psychological_notes: Evan has developed a sophisticated framework for understanding his own metacognitive limits. His ability to precisely map vertical (recursive) and horizontal (anticipatory) dimensions shows extraordinary self-awareness. The 'soup' metaphor captures the phenomenology of reaching cognitive limits—not failure but dissolution.
philosophical_underpinning: Consciousness can map but not exceed its own structural limits
therapeutic_direction: Client demonstrating mastery of metacognitive self-assessment
